content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Sounds trivial but far from it. Very good puzzle

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Really like the concept of this one. Seems trivial at first until you realise you can't bruteforce; then it seems really difficult; but eventually it's really quite doable. Explanation is clear; appreciate the many testcases.
W

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: I approved it previously

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
A bit simple i think, why the length of the word just 50? My solution probably yours as well is O(sigma*n), O(26*n).

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: The puzzle is neither too easy or too hard it is at just the right of difficulty to solve, and I learned a few things. hope others learn as well.
Difficulty Easy is for puzzles that can be solved via brute force.  Medium difficulty is recommended.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
Just tried it out and it's much harder to solve than it might initially look, definitely not beginner level. ðŸ˜… So I agree with those who would put it to medium difficulty.

Just tried it out and it's much harder to solve than it might initially look, definitely not beginner level. ðŸ˜… So I agree with those who would put it to medium difficulty.

One thing that I find confusing, the Statement says the index of the word in the dictionary should be returned, but you apparently start the indexing at 1?

I agree with @Klimpergeist that a modulo is needed for languages without arbitrary precision integers.

Am I wrong in thinking that there is a mistake in your solution here:

    for _iter in count:
        ways/=math.factorial(_iter)
    return int(ways)

and that it should be this instead:

    for _iter in count:
        ways //= math.factorial(_iter)
    return ways

because the result is not the same for the last test (rounding issues I assume).

Other than that, I found it weird to read Mississippi with a capital letter in the example. If everything is lowercase why not mississippi (and why not say only lowercase in the constraints too)

Also the #4 point of @5DN1L wasn't addressed, it still reads: 

Line 1: A string in the format "NUM is the index of WORD"

Finally, I found the output format very random, why not just the number?
In the test order, you could consider switching "mail" and "success". The latter is much harder due to the duplicate letters.

For this puzzle to be a simple one, I'd expect that you can just enumerate all possibilities. Due to the "monstrous" examples, this is not possible I think that medium is indeed the better classification.

Many languages require you to change the number format once the numbers approach 20 digits, so it might be nice to have an example with around 15 digits that can still be solved. As an alternative, some puzzles with huge solutions require you to print the solution modulo some reasonably large number, e.g. the prime 10^9+7. In your example, you might also just ask for the last 9 digits.

Goal
* Please format "abcd", "abdc", "bac" and "Mississippi" as {{constants}} and remove the quotation marks.

* Please change "repeating alphabets" to "repeating letters" (an alphabet is a set of letters, so "repeating alphabets" does not make sense in this context).

Input
* Please change "word of length less than 50" to "string [[word]]".

Output
* Please change "NUM is the index of WORD" to "[[NUM]]{{ is the index of }}[[word]]".

Constraints
* Please mention that [[word]] consists of lowercase letters only.

Cases
* Better to swap the last pair of test and validator as the current validator looks more demanding.

Thanks.

Hi there! You can suggest me any corrections or improvements to be made in this puzzle. Once they are completed... I will be updating the status of this puzzle to "Ready". I would also like to have your opinion on whether the level of this puzzle should be set to "Easy" or let it remain as "Medium"...
Your comments helped me shape the puzzle really well... Thanks! Is there anything you would like to add?
I have updated the testcases now @Klimpergeist. Will these work good in other languages? Or should I still work on lessening the numerical output of the last set of validators and testcases?
Changed it! Thanks

Hi, @Rafarafa... I worked on changing the testcases. And for these validators the existing code seems to work well. I corrected the mississippi case... Thanks. Well there is no specific reason for the output to be framed in such a way except for the fact that I liked it looking like that... Just a number wouldn't look that nice, would it?

Thanks anyways... Your comments really helped me a lot. Would you like to add anything? I would also like to know your opinion on setting the puzzle's difficulty to medium...

Hi @Pyradonis, thanks for reviewing. And yeah, the words in the dictionary are indexed from 1 and not from zero. i.e., the index of the first word is 1 and not 0...

Just wanted to touch base and see if you've had a chance to go through all the test cases yet?
Hi, now I have set the difficulty to Medium... Are there any other necessary corrections?

Hi Stephen, what is your take on adding the longest word ( pneumonoultramicroscopicsilicovolcanoconiosis ) to the testcases? Especially when the output turns out to be ( 4337586623089461057792833852852393167253 )....
Hi there! Can you make it a bit more specific? I don't get it....
Thanks a lot!

It's actually four duodecillion three hundred thirty-seven undecillion five hundred eighty-six decillion six hundred twenty-three nonillion eighty-nine octillion four hundred sixty-one septillion fifty-seven sextillion seven hundred ninety-two quintillion eight hundred thirty-three quadrillion eight hundred fifty-two trillion eight hundred fifty-two billion three hundred ninety-three million one hundred sixty-seven thousand two hundred fifty-three.... in words... lol
It might be a problem for people with older computers and in some languages time out if it does not do either of these 2 things then go for it
Yeah... that's a valid point... i am not making that change...
Hi... the time for validation ended ðŸ˜….. would you please consider re-approving the puzzle please?
Done

Not that I know of.  Now you just need to wait for 3 people to not only like your puzzle, but also attempt it and succeed, and then like it enough to approve, AND they need to have the ability unlocked to do so.  It'll take time
Oh.. thanks... Have you tried the solution yet, sir?
Hi, just got back to it. I've thought up an algorithm that solves all cases where there are only unique letters in the word, but I've still got to make it work with the others. ðŸ˜…
Hi Pyradonis, how's your algorithm been working so far?
Unfortunately I haven't had time to get back to it yet, but I love the challenge of coming up with a solution that doesn't involve actually creating permutations. :D

I like the new testcases, everything seems to be in bounds.

I think the highest bound that could potentially happen is: factorial(word.uniq.size), and I just tested that it is always < (1 << 64).

I rewrote your solution in C and passed everything. 

No modulo is needed now.

As for the input, I personally feel like it adds nothing and it's just random extra work, but maybe that's just me (it's not a big deal anyway, I guess).

I would like to see that every char is a lowercase english letter in the constraints though... And probably the C guys will want to know if they can factorial without overflowing (although this is more delicate, since you will be somehow giving a potential hint).

I think it's a medium yes. The optimization required to pass the last testcases is not trivial at all (imo).

Hi @Rafarafa, thanks for letting me know you worked out the solution. That was something I wanted to know to check the accuracy and correctness of my logic for those monstrous inputs. As for the lowercase, I have now mentioned them in the key points as well as the constraints... Is there anything else I should work on to improve this puzzle?
Looks good to me ðŸ‘

That range should be ok. Your largest number uses 53 bits, so everything is expressible with 64-bit numbers. I assume that this is fine for most languages.
I'm not sure how much extra effort you still have to put in nowadays to use 64-bit instead of 32-bit numbers in C-like languages, perhaps someone else can shed some light on this.
Can we really enumerate 'incomprehensibilities' with 7640649348286413 ? Medium should be the one

You're welcome.

Just one more thing:

Stub generator
* Please change "read n" to "read word" for consistency with other sections.

Thanks.
Done!
